Article Title: Willingness of Housing First Participants to Consider Supported-Employment Services
Abstract: Objective: People who had a recent history of homelessness and had mental illness were studied to determine how many wished to be employed and were willing to accept supported-employment services and the factors associated with a decision to decline services.Methods: People (N=194) with mental illness receiving Housing First were assessed at three-month intervals over 24 months. Analyses determined variables that were associated with accepting or declining randomization to supported-employment services. A regression model was used to determine the odds of obtaining employment.Results: Of the 133 (69%) participants who wanted work, 75 (56%) accepted and 58 (44%) declined randomization to services. Those who declined had lower odds of obtaining employment (OR=.42, p=.022), less education, and fewer arrests and had spent less time homeless.Conclusions: People with a recent history of homelessness who have a mental illness want work. People who declined randomization to supported-employment services had fewer barriers to employment but had reduced odds of obtaining employment.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design is a regression model, which lacks a rigorous evaluation and does not have a control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study does not directly address the intervention (supported-employment services) and lacks measures of employment outcomes. It focuses on willingness to consider supported-employment services rather than evaluating its effectiveness.
qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.study_design: Cross-sectional with longitudinal assessment over 24 months

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study focuses on the willingness of Housing First participants to consider supported-employment services, not on the effectiveness of the intervents themselves.
